Wherever we test the situation -and we test this legislation-we see that what has happened is like the evil that happened in the United Kingdom and has started to happen in Canada under growing socialism: Governments, faced with the sort of enormous and uncontrolled splurge in costs that Medicare will bring, start putting penalties on doctors, and start restricting the number of hospital beds and, therefore, the intake of patients. We have in New South Wales at this moment what is virtually an industrial strike without the commonsense of sorting out what the cost of a sessional payment ought to be. There is a squeeze all the time. There is a squeeze in respect of bulk billing. The aim is to try to get bulk billing to such a point that it is accepted by the patient and, therefore, puts us on the way to getting doctors overall to accept bulk billing-an easy step to socialisation or nationalisation.

In these pieces of legislation we have these things: A reduction in the stay before review of a patient from 60 days under the Fraser Government to 35 days under the Hawke Government; a change from four reasonable tests, which gave the doctor and the staff an opportunity to deal with the cases that demanded special attention, to one very rigid test; and a threat to the doctor that, unless he is precisely within the red tape, he will be punished in a most drastic way. One has to ask oneself: What sort of mind does that? Here is a Minister who, in respect of the assets test, has said repeatedly: 'The difference between Labor and the Opposition is that we trust people'. Those opposite trust the doctor to write a certificate then impose penalties of $10,000 or five years' gaol! They use arguments to suit themselves. There is no trust at all. There is absolute rigidity in the situation. Do they trust people? They have spent their time attacking the doctors. They have been proven wrong. The Penington Committee showed them how wrong they were in their attack. All the time they said that they would not trust the pathologists and the procedural people. Let the Minister remember their lack of trust and all their wild statements in condemnation of the procedural specialists, the pathologists, radiologists and so on. What was their margin of error? The Penington Committee said that there was an upsurge of 105 per cent in charges. Of course, those opposite were wrong to a mammoth degree.

Do they trust people? They say that they trust pensioners to fill in their forms, but they say: 'We do not trust the doctor, a highly respected person in this community, to make a proper medical judgment which only he or she can make, a judgment tempered with compassion, with sensitivity and with the humanity that this community would have. Not at all; we will have bureaucrats.' Perhaps they are not going to check up on the doctors. If they are not going to check up on the pensioners by knocking on doors, perhaps they are not going to knock on hospital doors. Is there a difference in this situation? After all, we have shown where we stand on this attack on procedural specialists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on. Don't start that stupid nonsense again. We know there will be an election on 1 December.

—Does Senator Coleman remember the attack on the radiologists and pathologists? Does Senator Coleman remember what happened to legislation on that in the debate in this Senate? Does Senator Coleman remember that step by step everything we said on that matter has been proven to be right and the Government to be wrong? Does Senator Coleman believe that it is right to hound doctors in this situation, that it is right to force a doctor to take compassion and sensitivity out of his judgment? That is exactly what is happening now. Does Senator Coleman also believe that it is right to restrict the number of nursing home beds so that we are forcing out people who cannot stand the test of requiring acute treatment, not people who are capable of domiciliary care? If they are sub-acute patients who require particular medication and so on, they will not stand up to this test. Where are they to go? That is the real test.

SPEECH.PARA: We had an incredible contribution by Senator Crowley. If I heard her correctly, she said: 'You are confusing the two things.' She was referring on the one hand to the 35-day rule and on the other to the shortage of nursing homes. She said they are linked but not totally linked, as though being kicked out of a hospital with nowhere to go for specialised medical treatment is not a direct path. She said: 'You never needed the 60 days. Thirty-five days is all right. The medical profession will tell you that'. Indeed, what she is saying and what presumably the Labor Government is saying is that all the cases that are coming before members of parliament now are frauds, they are phoney, and that there is no struggle to try to get people into private nursing homes. The argument that went on ad nauseam last night was that this was not true and that we were, in fact, putting up false cases. The fact of the matter is-the Government cannot get away with it-that there are such cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even one is enough.

—Senator Peter Baume says that even one is enough. One showing lack of compassion, sensitivity and accommodation is a demonstration of the breakdown because the one will be followed by two and then the tens and the hundreds. Putting it down to hard facts and summarising what has happened, the Hawke Government has reduced the period from 60 days to 35 days, reduced the test from four factors to one factor and imposed a ghastly and drastic penalty upon the doctor making it an absolutely rigid judgment. It has, by its own separate action, frozen the number of nursing home beds and, through its State governments, produced a chronic shortage of beds in ordinary hospitals and it has committed a ghastly misrepresentation on the people of Australia in the presentation of its advertisement.

SPEECH.PARA: If Medicare is good, if Medicare should be compulsory and if indeed it is all the things said about it, why does it need this advertising? In any case, that is a tissue of falsehoods. It is fundamentally not true to say that people can get into hospitals and stay in hospitals for free. It is an outright and wicked misrepresentation to say: 'But, of course, you still have the freedom to buy whatever private health insurance you feel is necessary. You can choose to have just that little bit of extra cover, or you can cover yourself for as much as you like. Either way it is your choice. You can decide how much health insurance you want and how much you want to pay for it.' That is simply not true.

On top of that, of course, are the hidden things: 'P.S. We forgot to tell you that we, the Hawke Government, have taken away the tax deductibility of your private insurance.' 'P.S. We would not say that because that would be embarrassing.' 'P.S. We forgot to tell you about our fiddle of the consumer price index so that we reduce inflation artificially.' 'P.S. We forgot to tell you that we are threatening the patient through the specialist doctor in the hospital'. All these things are done in the glory of why Medicare is good for the system. Medicare is good for the socialist system. Medicare is a system which decides that it will bring the doctor under the control of the State, that it will in fact reduce the complete confidentiality and flexibility of the doctor-patient relationship, that it will take away the opportunity for the better doctor to try to succeed more, for the differential in prices, and it will take away the right of people to insure and to cover their own expenses, the right of people to protect themselves in times of illness. That is a pretty far cry from that wonderful advertisement.

Yesterday I heard people talking about the honesty and truth of advertising in political life. That in itself is a scandalous advertisement but it is very opportune that it should be around at this moment to demonstrate the kinds of things that emerge when one puts this Bill, the Health Legislation Amendment Bill, in the totality of the Medicare package. Step by step what the Medicare package claims and what it does are two different things. In fact it badly restricts the services available to patients. It is restricting the doctor- patient relationship and, as it goes on and as it follows the pattern of failure overseas, the Australian community will be forced to pay more; not a one per cent levy but a 2 or 3 per cent levy as the costs engulf them for poorer and poorer services. I reject what is said in the advertisement and I reject the steps taken by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The people listening to this debate may be surprised to know that we are debating two pieces of legislation, the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1984 and the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984, as practically no reference was made to the social security legislation apart from a few passing references by Senator Messner and Senator Gietzelt. Obviously people have little interest. The whole of the debate, and certainly that part of Senator Sir John Carrick's speech which was relevant to the Health Legislation Amendment Bill, seems to hinge around objections to the 3B certificate system whereby patients, who are in a hospital for more than 35 days, need a doctor to sign that certificate. His debate also hinges around the difficulties as the Opposition sees them. Nothing could demonstrate more how dishonest the debate opposite is than some of the remarks of Senator Sir John Carrick, and I will go through them one by one, because he did ask a series of questions and I am certainly willing to answer them.

SPEECH.PARA: The point he brought up I think six times was that this Government had introduced what he called a ghastly and draconian fine of $10,000 or an alternative of five years' gaol for doctors who do not fill out the 3B form correctly. The facts are that the $10,000 fine and the five-year penalty for not filling out such a form correctly were introduced by the Fraser Government, the Fraser Government of which Senator Sir John Carrick was a senior Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a different set of considerations.

—We will come to that. It was the Fraser Government, and we transferred them over. That ghastly fine was introduced by the Government of which Senator Sir John Carrick was a senior Minister. He then came to the set of considerations. Under the previous Government there were four criteria. Our Government reduced the period from 60 days to 35 days because, as everyone who knows anything about it in this place knows, enormous rorts were going on. As anyone on the Senate committee investigating the matter at the moment will know even more there were enormous rorts going on under that 60-day system. We reduced it to 35 days and, at the request of the Australian Medical Association, we reduced the criteria from four to one. It was the medical profession who said : 'What we need is to make our professional judgment. You should rely on our professional judgment'.
—You attack the AMA every day.

—Just hold on. I will support it again in a minute. It requested this. It said: 'Look, these criteria are too bureaucratic. We want a simple system'. That simple system, in the best words anyone could come up with, applied to acute care. What really makes me annoyed is when someone such as Senator Walters comes in here, as she did last night-I will come to her remarks and other remarks made by Senator Sir John Carrick in a moment-and says that the words 'acute care' prevent doctors from signing that 3B certificate for a patient who has a terminal illness, a patient who has carcinoma and needs constant treatment or drainage of the chest et cetera, or says that a person who has had a stroke and who needs continuing medical treatment cannot have a doctor sign that 3B certificate because that is not regarded as acute care. That is an outrageous statement. I repeat what I said last night: Any doctor who refuses to sign the form under those circumstances is acting politically and the only one who will suffer will be the patient.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind Senator Sir John Carrick that I also am a doctor and I reserve the right to criticise members of my profession when they are wrong or when they act immorally or in a political way, and that is what they are doing in those circumstances. But in fact very few of them are doing it at all. If Senator Sir John Carrick has any evidence of someone being thrown out of a hospital because a doctor will not sign that 3B certificate when that patient should be kept there, I think Senator Sir John Carrick should come to the Minister for Health ( Dr Blewett) or the Department of Health and let them know about it, because we have not heard about it. He should know that the Department of Health can and will talk to any hospital which wants to put anyone out, and it will either negotiate a lower fee or negotiate another bed somewhere. If a 3B certificate cannot be signed it does not mean that no fee is paid but that it is reduced to a reasonable amount for someone who needs just nursing home type accommodation. That is the situation. The hospital gets a return more in line with the service it is delivering. That is the situation which exists. Under the old system people were kept in hospital so that the hospital would benefit by getting that higher fee, and it was a rort. The Department of Health, under the previous Government, knew it was a rort and held an extensive investigation into it. In fact on many occasions increasingly towards the end of its term of office, it was refusing to pay such fees.

The fine of $10,000 was the Fraser Government's fine. The reason the criteria were changed was that the medical profession wanted them changed and we thought it was reasonable because we thought we could rely on doctors to use their judgment. The fact that a few doctors were deliberately misusing their judgment for political purposes, I think, is a disgrace to the medical profession and in fact to the whole system of health delivery in this country. Senator Sir John Carrick tells us that we have a freeze on nursing home beds in this country. That is a deliberate untruth and I believe Senator Sir John Carrick knows that it is so.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is effectively a freeze.

—It is not effectively a freeze. In the first year 2,452 new nursing home beds went on stream. Certainly most of them were approved before, and another 3,316 nursing home beds have been approved in more recent times and approved under better criteria. What is more, unlike the old system, they will be built very soon. We will not have the situation that Dr Blewett and I faced when we came to government of having people who had received funding approval, going back many years, who had never provided a nursing home bed. We had a backlog of approvals which had been given years ago for all sorts of reasons. Because of poor judgment by those who gave the approvals, because they were given for political reasons and all sorts of other reasons, we had a backlog of approvals. There was a very real fear that if suddenly all the people who had received funding approval for nursing home beds took up their funds we would be in a dreadful state. We had an imbalance of nursing home beds throughout the community and we also had the fact, which is accepted by anyone who knows anything about the matter, that there are too many people in nursing home beds who should not be there.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last year we have looked at the criteria required for funding. We have asked people who have received approval to go ahead and do things or we will remove that approval. We have started to approve beds in places which have the greatest need. We have introduced the home assistance scheme, which Senator Gietzelt talked about, so that we can try to keep people out of nursing homes.

I object to the sorts of comments which come from people such as Senator Sir John Carrick, Senator Walters and others that we on this side of the chamber do not care, that we are heartless or whatever other expressions they use. The problem with aged persons accommodation in this country is that over the years we have had a gross maldistribution of nursing home beds. They have been in the wrong places. They have been in the eastern suburbs of Sydney instead of the western suburbs of Sydney. At one stage a few years ago there were none north of Bendigo in Victoria. Up to 30 per cent of people in nursing home beds should not be there. They should be either in their own homes or in less expensive and less dependent accommodation. Everybody knows that. Every report on aged care in this country has stated that over and over again. This Government will do something about it and it is the first government to do something about it. But what happens? We are accused of closing down nursing homes, not building nursing homes, keeping people out on the street and keeping people out of hospitals, and that is nonsense.

Senator Sir John Carrick made some remarks about what he thought of the behaviour of honourable senators in the Senate last night and in particular about my behaviour. I cannot let the matter pass even though it is not relevant to the legislation. It was spoken about last night. What I consider despicable behaviour in this place is for honourable members or honourable senators to introduce into this place debate about the personal health and the personal health problems, including diagnoses, of either honourable members or honourable senators or their children. I think that behaviour is disgusting and unethical even for an honourable senator, let alone a nurse. That is what provoked me last night.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. Standing order 418 makes it quite clear that all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on honourable senators shall be considered highly disorderly. Senator Grimes has referred specifically to Senator Walters in a way which I believe breaches that standing order. I ask you to bring him to order.
—He never mentioned any names.

—I make the point that last night Senator Walters raised a matter in debate which related to the administration of Medicare as it affected a particular member of Parliament. Senator Grimes said that that was unethical and improper behaviour-I do not know whether these are his exact words- especially as it related to a member of the nursing profession. I believe that he is in breach of standing order 418 and, in the interest of fair debate here, I ask that the honourable senator withdraw.

—I withdraw. I have no reason to sustain that debate. I merely point out now in general terms that if we get to the stage in this place when it becomes commonplace for the personal medical diagnosis of either honourable senators or their children or relatives to be bandied around this place, I can assure Senator Sir John Carrick that we will be in a deplorable state because God knows where it will end up. It will not be me who is doing it and it will not be me who is doing it in reply, but it will end up that way.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact about Dr Blewett's daughter's case is that Dr Blewett asked for no privileges and received no privileges that any other member of the general public in the Australian Capital Territory cannot request and receive. I think everyone knows about the matter; they have heard it 1,000 times. Dr Blewett preferred and his daughter preferred to be operated on by a salaried specialist. He made that request and the salaried specialist did the operation. The advertisements which preceded the introduction of Medicare and which followed the introduction of Medicare in Canberra stated: 'You can have a doctor of your choice as a Medicare patient in a public hospital in Canberra. The doctor admits you to a public hospital for any pre-arranged service and can continue to treat you in hospital'. Everyone knows that that is the situation in Canberra. It is certainly not the situation throughout Australia. No special privileges were requested.

It is no secret that when this happened a well-known doctor-I think this is appalling-in this city was touting this story around the Press Gallery and around the newspapers in Canberra. The newspapers having seen the facts said: ' That is not much of a story'. Of course the only way it could become a story is if it were brought up in the House of Representatives or in this place.

I repeat: If the diagnoses and the personal nature of a matter relating not only to a member but also to his children or his relatives are brought up, we will be in strife. I got very annoyed about it and I make no bones about that. When the matter came up in the adjournment debate I was pleased to hear last night another honourable senator on the Opposition side who, when I made the point that if this happens we will have some horrible exchanges in this place, said: 'Two wrongs do not make a right'. I said: 'No, two wrongs do not make a right. It will not be me who brings up those issues'. At least the honourable senator admitted that what had happened from the Opposition side in this case was wrong. It was wrong and it will always be wrong.

I think that the standard of debate and the standard of behaviour not only in this regard but also in other regards has reached a level, this year and last year, which is not healthy for the Westminster system of government about which Senator Sir John Carrick is so concerned. Prying into people's personal affairs in this place will not lead us down the track to better government, better democracy or better debate. However, if people such as Senator Sir John Carrick expect us on this side of this place to sit back and take it, expect us on this side to sit back and say: 'Yes, it is perfectly all right for conservatives to say what they like about people on our side of this place and we will be gentlemen and ladies and not respond', he is mistaken. He will continue to be mistaken but in the end we will all be the losers.

I believe that I have dealt with the matters raised by Senator Sir John Carrick about the fine which, I repeat, was introduced by the Fraser Government and the single criterion for a certificate about which Senator Walters made a great fuss last night. It was introduced at the request of the Australian Medical Association. I have pointed out that there has been no freeze on nursing home beds in this country and nor will there be; but there will certainly be a more efficient delivery of nursing home beds in this country.

I make one final point in relation to Senator Sir John Carrick's comments. He referred to the industrial dispute in New South Wales between the orthopaedic surgeons in particular and the New South Wales Government. He seemed-I may be incorrect-to come down on the side of the doctors. He said: 'They are being grossly provoked'. I point out gently to Senator Sir John Carrick that the Australian Medical Association in New South Wales-I again support it-does not approve of the doctors' actions and nor should it. Why should it? It is very easy for medical practitioners who have very considerable private wealth to say: 'We are willing to sacrifice gains that we get from our profession, for a principle'. Some of their colleagues are not too willing to do it because they rely on the income they get from their profession, unlike a couple of people who are most vocal in this dispute at present. It is no wonder that the Australian Medical Association disowns them, and will, I believe, continue to disown them.

The other general issues that I raise include the 3B certificate. Senator Sir John Carrick and other honourable senators may be surprised to know that I think that the 3B certificate system is not perfect, nor is it completely satisfactory . I, as a senator, have made representations to the Minister for Health to have some aspects of it changed. That is fair enough. When one introduces a system like this one will always need changes. We are making changes now and not all those changes necessitate legislation, as Dr Blewett pointed out in the other place. Some of those changes are being made by regulation. We are, in fact, introducing criteria now because the AMA, despite wanting the single criterion and wanting to rely entirely on the professional judgment of the doctor, now seems to have some difficulty operating under that system. If necessary we will introduce criteria and those criteria will be discussed with the medical profession and those who have to operate the system.

Many other extraneous matters were brought in today by Senator Sir John Carrick and others. These matters are often brought in in this place. Senator Sir John Carrick said that the waiting lists are long in public hospitals. Indeed, they are long and they have increased a bit since Medicare came into effect. But they have always been long. As long as I have been in this place, senators have been talking about the length of the waiting lists in hospitals. For Senator Sir John Carrick to suggest that the fact that some people die before they can have open heart surgery is something which has suddenly happened since the introduction of Medicare is nonsense. It will always happen and it always has happened. Senator Sir John Carrick cannot produce any evidence that that happens more frequently now.

TALK.START.PARA: —The queues have increased; the waiting times have increased.

—Did it ever occur to Senator Watson that one of the reasons the queues have increased is that people may now be trying to have surgery that they could not have done before because they could not afford it before? No, and it has never occurred to Senator Sir John Carrick either.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had all the raving and huffing and puffing about no gap insurance. I was in this place when the AMA and the medical profession violently opposed gap insurance because they work on the gypsy principle that medicine cannot be practised unless someone crosses the palm with silver and gap insurance would take away that concept. We have been through all those debates in the introduction of the Medicare legislation. If Senator Sir John Carrick thinks that in the vast majority of countries comparable with Australia that have a national health scheme of some type or another-all the social democracies of Western Europe-vast numbers of people are saying 'Get rid of our national health system, we want to go back to the free enterprise system of the United States where the difference between what people can afford-

TALK.START.PARA: —Who has been advocating it?

—Senator Sir John Carrick has been advocating it. Senator Watson should not open his mouth too wide. In a place like the United States the difference between what people get if they can afford it and what they do not get when they cannot afford it is appalling.
—That is not true.

—Senator Sir John Carrick should ask Senator Baume, who has worked in public hospitals in the United States. He should ask him about doctors having to put their hands in their own pockets in order to give people some of the least expensive and simplest but essential drugs. We all know about that; some of us have actually been there. Most comparable countries have national health schemes because governments have come to realise that this is the only way to bring equity to the system. Most of these schemes-not all of them-retain the right of private practice, but none of them retains the right of private practice to the extent that the national health insurance scheme does in this country. None of them uses public funds to prop up private practice the way the national health insurance scheme in this country does. To condemn our scheme as being like the British scheme, for instance, is to show a profound ignorance of the difference between the two systems.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank honourable senators for supporting the Social Security and Repatriation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984 and I thank the Opposition for not actually opposing the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1984, although one would have thought from the debates that there would be a mass revolution about this. There is an amendment, the usual amendment that we see in this place, trying to slap the Government on the wrist. It is based on the gross misconception of what the 3B certificate system is all about. To suggest that we scrub the system, get rid of the 35-day rule and forget all about 3B certificates et cetera is to express a profound ignorance of how the system works. The previous Government had a 60-day rule. That system was rorted. The previous Government had criteria on how doctors should make a judgment at the end of 60 days. The doctors did not like it, they wanted a simple system. We gave them that. The previous Government introduced the $10,000 fine and the five years gaol, not this Government. I am sorry that Senator Sir John Carrick finds it so ghastly, so horrible, so draconian and all the other words that he used, but he did not seem to think it was so when he was a senior Cabinet Minister in the previous Government when that was introduced. So I am afraid I cannot take his criticism very seriously.

A series of Opposition senators have ranged broadly over the whole of the health system. They have had a bit of a lash at the social security system here and there and have made no constructive suggestions except Senator Sir John Carrick who seems to think that it is constructive to say that we should chuck out the health insurance scheme and introduce a scheme similar to that in the United States. We have had pseudo-economic lectures from Senator Sir John Carrick, which he puts into every speech he makes in this place, on the reduction of the consumer price index by Medicare. We have had gross misstatements about the effect of the fines and the 3B certificates. We have had no hard evidence and no positive suggestions for the future. I thank honourable senators for their co-operation. I wish we could have got the legislation through a bit faster and I hope that we can get it through the Committee stage a little more quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement.
—What is it about?
—It is a statement relating to the speech by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes).
—I suggest that Senator Walters use the Standing Orders. One of our people was refused leave yesterday. Unless she tells us what the matter is about we cannot grant leave.
—Is leave granted?
—No.
—In that case, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are several areas in which Senator Grimes claimed that I was not telling the truth in my speech last night. I would like to deal with those one at a time. First, when I was speaking about the 3B certificates that must be signed by doctors after patients have been in hospital for 35 days, I was explaining that under our system when we were in government doctors could use four different guidelines. Under the present system there is only one, and that is acute care. I said that the doctors were objecting to this. Senator Grimes said that that was not true. Again today, he said that the doctors have asked the Government to withdraw the four and make it only one. I have been speaking to the Australian Medical Association, following the speech last night, and at the same time as Senator Grimes was making those untruthful statements in the Senate today, and I was assured that the AMA had never asked the Government to withdraw those-
—Who were you talking to? Say who you were talking to, come on.
—I was talking to George Repin.
—Oh! Dear, oh dear, oh dear.
—Senator Grimes is suggesting that George Repin is not telling me the truth?

—I am suggesting that you were not asking him the right questions . I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. We have had a request for a personal explanation to be made in this place, because, one would assume, Senator Walters claims to have been misrepresented. With due respect, she is now making another second reading debate speech.
—No, I am not.

—Wait a minute. Senator Walters is saying 'I made this speech last night; Senator Grimes disagreed with me; I have now gone away and got new evidence'-and all that sort of thing. If we allow this, we will have personal explanations endlessly after every speech made in this place. I do not mind people giving personal explanations. I certainly think that people should have the right to claim that they have been misrepresented. But when it is extended to the extent that we have a repeat second reading debate speech, I think that the whole system will break down.

—Thank you, Senator Grimes. I am ready to rule on that point of order now. Senator Walters, you have leave to make a personal explanation. You have to confine it to how you are affected personally, and so far, in my view, you have been adhering to that, but you must not stray beyond that point or debate the matter at all.

—I will not stray, Mr Deputy President. I was told that I was not telling the truth. I am just indicating that I was expressing the truth. George Repin told me this morning that the AMA never asked the Government to withdraw the four. He said that the 3B certificate, as a fait accompli, was presented to the AMA and the AMA was asked for its response-that is, the single acute care section on its own. The AMA's response was that if the doctors had the full choice of whether patients stay in or not, they would not have any complaint. The AMA has since asked the Government for guidelines.
—I said that.
—That is not what Senator Grimes has said.
—I have said that, Senator.
—Indeed, Senator Grimes made it very clear that the AMA asked the Government to withdraw the four.

—Senator Walters, you are getting very wide of the point. You have leave to make a personal explanation. You are not seeking to do so on the ground of misrepresentation, which is a different ground. You must show how you were personally affected. I accept the earlier point, where Senator Grimes said that you misled the Senate in some way; that is proper. But you must confine your remarks to how you were personally affected by what has happened.
—Senator Grimes has just been proven to be telling untruths. On the second issue, as regards Dr Blewett's use of Medicare, I said last night:

SPEECH.PARA: He did not just take the doctor on duty. It was not good enough for him.
That is the situation. Generally, in all the capital cities apart from Canberra, if Australians have a problem and they have no private--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walters, I cannot see how this is affecting you personally. You must confine your explanation as to how you were personally affected.
—I have been misrepresented in the situation that Senator--

—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. Standing order 418 states that no senator shall use and/or imply any imputation of improper motives. Senator Walters has just implied an improper motive to Dr Blewett. It is untenable. It is contrary to standing order 418. I ask that the honourable senator withdraw it.

—Thank you, Senator Crowley. I ruled on this matter last night. Certainly standing order 418 has that nature, as you have said, but describing the behaviour of the Minister for Health, in these circumstances, is not criticising his motives within the terms of standing order 418. Senator Walters, on this explanation for which you have leave, you must confine yourself to how you were personally affected, and you must not reopen the debate.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. All that I said was that he did not use the system as the rest of Australia must use it.
—That is not what you said, Senator. You said that it was not good enough for him. That is to imply that you understand what he thinks. It is outrageous.
—He did not use the system as the rest of Australia must use it, and I still maintain that that is exactly what has happened within Canberra.
—You are a disgraceful woman; absolutely outrageous.
—Order! Senator Grimes will cease interjecting.
—It is the sort of behaviour she goes on with in Tasmania.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Grimes!

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it notices of motion Nos 113 and 135. I wish to deal principally with notice of motion No. 135, which seeks to establish a Select Committee on Video Censorship.
—Order! Senator Reid, I understand that if you wish to debate the notices cognately you will require leave of the Senate to do so.
—I seek leave to debate the two matters cognately.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dealing firstly with notice of motion No. 135, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Video Censorship, be appointed to report on the operation of Regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 in relation to videotapes and videodiscs and in particular:
(a) the effectiveness of such legislation to adequately control the importation , production, reproduction, sale and hire of violent, pornographic or otherwise obscene material;
(b) whether the present classification system, as applied by the Film Censorship Board, is adequate as a basis for import and point-of-sale controls;
(c) whether video retailers are observing the conditions of sale or hire attached to classified material, particularly in relation to children under 18 years;

(d) whether Regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations is adequate in identifying categories of prohibited material, and operating effectively in preventing the importation of videotapes/discs falling within the prohibited categories;
(e) examine the extent to which videotapes and videodiscs containing pornographic and violent material are available to the community in general;
(f) whether children under the age of 18 years are gaining access to videotapes /discs containing violent pornographic or otherwise obscene material;

(g) whether the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 should be amended to make it an offence for persons purchasing or hiring 'X' classified videotapes/discs to allow, suffer or negligently permit children to view such material;
(h) whether cinemas should be permitted to screen for public exhibition 'X' classified material, subject to prohibition from entry of persons under the age of 18 years;

(i) whether films which merit an 'X' classification are being produced in Australia and, if so, whether Australian men and women are adequately protected by existing law from pressure to act in such films; and
(j) the likely effects upon people, especially children, of exposure to violent , pornographic or otherwise obscene material.
(2) That the Committee consist of 6 Senators, as follows:
(a) 3 to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) 2 to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c) 1 Independent Senator, to be nominated by the Independent Senator.
(3) That the Committee proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by the Leader of the Government.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy- Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That the quorum of the Committee be 3 members.

(8) The the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit.

(9) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub- committee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(10) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(11) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(12) That the Committee report to the Senate by 31 March 1985.

(13) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may send its report to the President of the Senate or, if the President is not available, to the Deputy-President, who is authorised to give directions for its printing and circulation and, in such event, the President or Deputy-President shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

I will not go through all the paragraphs of the motion but will refer to only some of them. The Committee will be asked to report on the effectiveness of the legislation and its ability to control adequately the importation, production, reproduction, sale and hire of violent, pornographic or otherwise obscene material; to look into the question of whether or not the present classification system, as applied by the Film Censorship Board, is adequate as a basis for import and point-of-sale controls; to check on whether or not video retailers are observing the conditions of sale or hire attached to classified material, particularly in relation to children under 18 years of age; to look at other aspects of the regulations and their ability to operate effectively; to examine the extent to which this material is available generally in the community, and the extent to which children under the age of 18 years are gaining access to it. There are, of course, a number of important aspects in the inquiry. We have also included in the motion the number of senators who shall be on the proposed Select Committee on Video Censorship, the manner in which it shall operate, and when it shall report, that is, 31 March 1985.

Amendments will be put forward by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and Senator Harradine which are acceptable to the Opposition. The Attorney will seek to effect a transfer in due course to a joint committee of the Parliament and to report as a joint committee. Perhaps that will happen; perhaps not. So far the record for establishment of a joint committee has not been a good one and it is for that reason we feel that a Senate select committee should be set up. At the last count the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette indicated that 948 films had been classified as X and 16 had been refused classification from 1 January 1984. I seriously wonder about the ability of a group of, I think, seven people to examine these films and many others and not become desensitised to the material. It may well be that that consideration and the classification of the material are aspects that will occupy the attention of the Committee.

It is unfortunate perhaps that the whole debate has come to this stage. I suggest that if the matter had been dealt with by way of a Bill right at the beginning, rather than by way of subordinate legislation in the form of regulations and an ordinance, a committee could have been set up in February of last year to look into the implications; but that time has passed. We had the opportunity to take action when on 7 June the Senate passed a motion to set up a joint committee. That motion went to the House of Representatives before it rose for the winter recess on 7 June, but many months have been lost. I think that community reaction to the legislation is such that a committee of the Senate must get under way as soon as possible.

I believe the Attorney-General misread public opinion when he stated earlier this year that community attitudes have changed to the point where people want the kind of X-rated material available for home use. I do not know what the Select Committee's findings will be. It may well find that the Attorney-General is right, but it is my observation, from representations made to me, that he is wrong. In fact, one might suggest almost that he has been a slow learner in getting round to considering this matter. It was not until 20 August that he agreed, publicly at least, that a joint committee should be set up. There have been many letters to honourable senators and members of the House of Representatives, many letters have been published in newspapers, and many petitions have been presented by constituents expressing their concern about the legislation. I believe they are entitled to have the matter reviewed. It is the advent of the video cassette recorder which has changed this issue so much, and perhaps many of us did not realise soon enough what the effect would be. I think we need to look into the matter. The community is entitled to have the opportunity of expressing its views. As the Senate is aware, a meeting was held in Canberra which 2,000 people attended. It was a very large public meeting and was held on a very cold night. Those people came to make known their views about the legislation. I cannot see that there has been any good reason for a delay in setting up the Committee. It just seems a pity that so much time has been lost.

The Australian Capital Territory has become an island in that New South Wales has not gone along with the classification. Most States seem to be either against it or very concerned about it. I would say that now is the time to get on with setting up the Committee. We should get it established and functioning this week so that it can place advertisements, call for submissions and, over the recess, start looking at the material which undoubtedly will be put before it. I am sorry that I will not be able to be a member of the Committee, as the Territory senators expire-perhaps that is the correct word-when the Parliament is dissolved and do not exist again until the Parliament resumes. Territory senators do not have the same status as the other 60 senators. Even though I would like to have been a member of the Committee, I think it is important that it gets under way and gets on with the job that needs to be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion which was moved by Senator Reid. It is important that an examination of matters relating to video censorship take place, and that examination is long overdue. I do not intend to delay the Parliament for long because I believe the sooner the Senate Select Committee on Video Censorship is established the better. A number of people throughout the community believe that such a committee has already been established, not the least being the Attorney-General of Victoria who, in a Press statement issued a couple of weeks ago, referred to a committee having been established by the Federal Parliament. The problem is that until now such a committee has not been appointed.

SPEECH.PARA: As far back as June of this year the Senate adopted a resolution requesting the establishment of a joint parliamentary committee to investigate video materials. That resolution was transmitted to the House of Representatives and was not dealt with adequately by that House before it got up for the winter recess. In fact it was dealt with very late one night and into the early hours of the morning. There was a similar occurrence on two subsequent occasions when the matter was brought forward in the House of Representatives. As of last week when the House of Representatives rose for the forthcoming election the matter had not been finally determined. Therefore, because of the problems being experienced within the community with regard to this issue, it is necessary for the Senate to take the action that is being proposed today.

I do not want to delay the Senate so I have risen simply to move the amendments that have been circulated in my name. The first amendment seeks to leave out the word 'Censorship' in the title of the proposed committee and proposes that the committee be called the Select Committee on Video Material. In the second amendment I propose in the general terms of reference to include an examination of the operation of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations. I believe that this amendment is necessary to ensure that the Committee will be able to pursue all of the legislation which it seeks to consider. My third amendment proposes to insert after paragraph (1) (c) new sub-paragraph (ca) so that the Committee can inquire and report on the following:

Whether 'R' rated videos should be permitted to be displayed for sale or hire in the same area and side by side with 'G', 'PG' and 'M' rated videos and, if not, what restrictions should be imposed on the display of 'R' rated material;

At present there is a good deal of discussion on the question of R-rated and X- rated material. Under the provisions of the Australian Capital Territory Classifications of Publications Ordinance, for a video to be classified as R- rated it must either not pass the reasonable adult person test-that is to say that it depicts sex, violence, crime, et cetera in a manner that would give offence to the reasonable adult person- or be defined as being 'unsuitable for the viewing of a minor'. I can think of R-rated videos which it could be argued do meet the reasonable adult person test but which are not suitable for the viewing of minors. One such example, it could be argued, is One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been prescribed as a school text.

—Before the Film Censorship Board can classify a film as R- rated it must, under the Ordinance, decide that that film either does not meet the reasonable adult person test or is classed as unsuitable for the viewing of minors. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest has been classified by the Film Censorship Board as R-rated. Therefore in the view of the Board it either does not meet the reasonable adult person test or is unsuitable for the viewing of minors. Those are the facts. All that I am saying is that there are two types of R-rated material. Clearly the Committee will need to examine this aspect at some stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to move another amendment which seeks to insert after paragraph (1) (g) new sub-paragraph (ga) so that the Committee can examine and report on the following:
Whether the sale, hire, distribution or exhibition of films and videotapes/ discs that would, under existing laws, be accorded a classification above 'R' should be made unlawful;

One of the defects of the motion before us is that it does not say whether material that is currently classified as X-rated or material that is classified as being above R-rated should not be permitted by law in Australia to be made available for sale, hire, distribution or exhibition. It is high time that the people of Australia had an opportunity to have their say on this matter. We know the problems that exist as a result of the new provisions introduced by this Government which have legalised for the first time in Australia the general importation of hard core pornography and its commercialisation in the Australian Capital Territory. I believe that the public has been concerned about this matter from the start. This Committee will give the public the opportunity to have its say.

The establishment of a select committee of this character is an extension of the representative functions of members of parliament. We are here after all to represent our constituents. Our constituents will have in this Committee a sounding board, if you like, for their views. I do hope the reasonable and responsible views of the community will be put forward to this Committee in a logical manner so that it can examine the ramifications of the existing laws, the ramifications of the widespread availability of video material in the community at present and not least the effect of this material on children.

I had proposed further amendments which would have dealt with print material containing pornographic, violent or obscene publications. It has been suggested by some video distributors that the concentration by members of parliament and the public is on video material and that people have ignored the fact that objectionable print publications are widespread. There is a great concern about objectionable print publications. I would have liked this Committee to have dealt with the public's viewpoint on that matter. It is not beyond the bounds of possibility that evidence will be produced to the Committee that there is a need for consideration of the laws relating to such material. I am sure that the Committee will receive evidence of this. I am told that it is the concern, particularly of the Opposition and the Government, that we should focus now on video material, so I have agreed not to press at this stage that the Committee's terms of reference be extended to cover objectionable print publications. With those reservations and with the following amendments I support the motion for the establishment of the Committee. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to move my four amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Paragraph (1), leave out 'Censorship', insert 'Material'.
2. Paragraph (1), after 'operation of', insert 'the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations,'
3. After sub-paragraph (1) (c), insert the following new sub-paragraph:

'(ca) whether ''R'' rated videos should be permitted to be displayed for sale or hire in the same area and side by side with ''G'', ''PG'' and ''M'' rated videos and, if not, what restrictions should be imposed on the display of ''R'' rated material;'.
4. After sub-paragraph (1) (g), insert the following new sub-paragraph:
'(ga) whether the sale, hire, distribution or exhibition of films and videotapes/discs that would, under existing laws, be accorded a classification above ''R'' should be made unlawful;'.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I foreshadowed earlier this morning, the Government will not oppose this motion which is consistent with what has always been our willingness to establish a parliamentary committee as soon as possible to take evidence and report on the kinds of matters set out in these terms of reference. It is unfortunate that the pressure of business in the House of Representatives was such that the motion for the establishment of a joint committee did not come to us sooner. But in any event it will be apparent to honourable senators that that motion would have been aborted with the forthcoming dissolution of the House of Representatives anyway. The establishment of a Senate committee certainly makes it possible for research to be done, inquiries to be set in train and submissions to be garnered over the whole period between now and when we resume. But it remains the Government's desire that the committee looking at this question be a joint select committee. It is with that in mind that I previously foreshadowed and will now move amendments to the terms of reference making it clear that, on the resumption of the Parliament, the work of the Senate Select Committee on Video Censorship will be subsumed into the work of a larger joint select committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, I shall seek leave to move the five amendments circulated in my name, three of which are minor tidying-up amendments to make it clear that the X classification referred to in Senator Reid's terms of reference would be more appropriately described as a classification above R. More particularly, amendments No. 4 and No. 5 on the circulated list make it clear that it is the view of the Senate that the Senate Committee should have a relatively limited time span. I seek leave to move my amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Paragraph 1 (g), leave out ' ''X'' classified videotapes/discs' insert ' videotapes/discs classified above ''R'' '.
2. Paragraph 1 (h), leave out ' ''X'' classified material', insert 'material classified above ''R'' '.
3. Paragraph 1 (i), leave out ' an ''X'' classifcation', insert ' a classification above ''R'' '.
4. After paragraph 8, insert the following new paragraphs:

'8A. That the Committee operate until such time as a Joint Select Committee with terms of reference similar to those proposed in Message No. 359 from the House of Representatives is appointed by both Houses of the Parliament.

8B. That on the establishment of such Joint Select Committee, the Committee be authorised to release to it transcript of evidence and other documents received by it relevant to the inquiry of the Joint Committee.'
5. Paragraph 12, after 'That', insert ', subject to paragraphs 8A and 8B,'.

Amendment No. 5 is that the reporting date of the Senate Select Committee be adjusted to reflect the probability that it may go out of existence when the joint committee is established. It would be the intention of the Government to establish the joint committee immediately upon the resumption of the Parliament, thus enabling matters subject to the terms of reference to be dealt with expeditiously. The existing motion, just passed in the House of Representatives, provides for a reporting date of 30 April. The motion now before us to establish the Senate Select Committee provides for a reporting date of 31 March. I suspect that the April date might be the more realistic date. But that matter can be discussed closer to that time.

These terms of reference moved by Senator Reid differ in some slight respects from those accepted in the House of Representatives. I do not seek in any way to quarrel with them nor, as has been apparent in the last few minutes, does the Government quarrel with the amendments moved by Senator Harradine which again vary the terms of reference in some essentially marginal respects and which have been the subject of discussion between the parties this morning.

The Government will seek to move quickly this week to establish the Senate Select Committee so that it might seek submissions and have a secretary working on commissioning research and doing all the other sorts of things that are necessary when a parliamentary inquiry is set in train. I do not want to be taken as accepting any of the more extravagant assertions that have been made from time to time about the state of crisis in which the nation is now plunged by virtue of the operation of the present system. I simply make the point, as I have all along, that this is a difficult area of social policy. It is one on which strongly held competing views are held. The Government is certainly willing that there be an objective consideration of how the new law has been operating. We think it has now been operating for long enough for some such objective assessment to be made. We wish first the Senate Committee and subsequently the joint select committee the best of luck in getting on with what will be a difficult job and hope, of course, that in the process it does not come back too slavering, depraved and corrupted by virtue of its exposure to the material which will be before it.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the motion to establish the Senate Select Committee on Video Censorship, General Business notice of motion No. 135, because we agree that only a Senate committee can be guaranteed continued existence beyond the election to be held on 1 December and, indeed, beyond the dissolution of the House of Representatives, which will be next week. We are now and always have been opposed to violent, cruel and sadistic material on videotape. We understand fully and sympathise with the concern of the community about this matter, especially the concern of parents about the effect of this material on their children which is a very widespread and deep feeling. It has become apparent since this matter was first seriously debated earlier this year.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this year, because of Australian Democrat initiatives, we were able to make some significant improvements in the regulations so that violent, cruel and sadistic material which is gratuitous is now excluded definitely and absolutely by the Customs regulations. Those regulations were also changed to make classification of this material mandatory rather than voluntary, as was the case in the past. So we are making some significant progress. We made progress then. I made the point in speaking to that issue that this must be a continuing debate in the community, that we had not reached the end of it and that it was necessary for us to establish a community consensus on what was acceptable, right and proper and what the community wanted. In the view of the Australian Democrats nothing could achieve this better than a Senate committee which could go to the public and ask them what they feel. Then the Senate, the Parliament, and hopefully the Government, can be guided by the results of that. On that basis we support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to take up much of the time of the Senate. I point out that the Opposition has at last been able to establish a committee relatively promptly now that the House of Representatives has gone into recess. The statement by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that the Government has always shown a willingness to set up such a committee has to be taken with a grain of salt. When during debates the Opposition suggested a committee, Senator Evans-we need only to refer to Hansard for this-very definitely said that it was unnecessary and that only the likes of the wowsers on this side would object to this material. But it is enough that the honourable senator has seen the light and I am delighted to see that he is joining us. I am only too happy to accept his amendments for the Senate Select Committee on Video Censorship to abide by. I am also only too happy to accept the amendments put forward by Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has been dilly-dallying in the setting up of this Committee. The Opposition asked that a committee be set up well before the winter recess. The request went to the House of Representatives and on that occasion the House of Representatives was again too busy to deal with the request. It was not until Parliament resumed for the Budget session that the Special Minister of State, Mr Young, put forward his proposition to set up a committee. That was, as has been said today, a rather strange way to go about it in view of the fact that a request from the Senate was already before him. However, he agreed to that but it was the shortest lived committee ever. I presume people had been chosen from the various parties to go on to that committee but the committee never met. Indeed, without Senator Reid's motion, we would have been waiting until next February for action to be taken in the setting up of a committee. As a result of Senator Reid's motion we are now able to go ahead in the Senate and get it under way. Again, I am only too happy to join with Senator Evans in agreeing that, when the House of Representatives resumes, it should be a joint committee.

I do not think there is any need to elaborate further on the need for this Committee. It is very obviously required by the people of Australia from the number of signatures that have come in. It is very timely to say to the people of Australia that their signatures on the petitions that come into this House and into the lower House certainly do have an effect on the government of the day. If there are enough signatures, a government does listen. This in particular is one area where the thousands of signatures that have been brought into the Senate have had their effect. The Government has now said that it will agree with the Opposition and allow this Committee to get under way and I am delighted to hear that.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Notice of motion No. 113 deals principally with the call for a moratorium on the sale, hire and distribution of X-rated material in the Australian Capital Territory and across Australia pending the outcome, it says in the motion, of a joint select committee of inquiry into pornographic videos. In fact I will seek leave to amend that to be the senate select committee of inquiry and then the joint-
—Parliamentary inquiry.

—I will amend that to be a parliamentary inquiry. The motion also sets out some of the reasons for a moratorium. That is, it asks the Senate to recognise that the New South Wales Government is to ban X-rated videos which makes the Australian Capital Territory somewhat of an island. It also asks the Senate to recognise the concern in the community, especially in the Territory, about the implications of the influx and importation of this material. It seems to me that, if there is to be a committee to look into these important matters, there should be a moratorium during the time that the Committee is operating and reporting. Who knows what the outcome and recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Video Censorship will be? But I think the issues that relate to the call for a moratorium have been adequately expressed and put in the debate that has gone on during this year. It rather speaks for itself. At this time it would be more appropriate to try to complete the matter than to debate it at length. I seek leave to amend notice of motion No. 113.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) recognises the concern in the community in the Australian Capital Territory , New South Wales and other parts of Australia about the influx and importation of 'X'-rated videos for sale, hire, reproduction and distribution;
(b) notes that the New South Wales Government is to ban the sale, hire, reproduction and private distribution of all 'X'-rated videos in that State; and

(c) calls on the Federal Government to place a moratorium on the importation, sale, hire, reproduction and private distribution in the Australian Capital Territory and across Australia of all 'X'-rated and other sexually sadistic and violent videos pending the outcome of the proposed Parliamentary Committee of Inquiry into pornographic videos.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unquestionably this whole area of video material censorship is now in a shambles. In fact there has been a revolt amongst the States. I will not say that the States are revolting but they have revolted on this matter. We now have a situation where all of the States have expressed the view that X-rated videos should be banned. But faced with this revolt from the States, at least over the X-rated videos, the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) has blandly stated that X-rated videos will be abandoned and a new R-plus classification established into which over 90 per cent of existing X-rated material will be placed, containing hard core pornography without significant violence which he describes as erotic material.
—I didn't say 'will be'. I said 'will consider it'.

—He says he will consider it. I say that that is not only a sleight-of-hand but also an attempt to degrade the true meaning of the word ' erotic'. I take this point now and publicly so that the Government does not fall into that. The material now approved by the Film Censorship Board for the X rating and for which the Attorney-General is seeking to have discussions to transfer to the R-plus rating includes all the depictions which have been expressed from time to time in this place. I do not intend to use all of the descriptions, but in no way can that material be described as erotic. The fact is that we have to distinguish between eroticism and pornography.
—What turns me on and what turns you on.

—No. As I said once before, one of the most evocative of erotic poems is contained in the Bible in the 'Song of Songs', the 'Canticle of Canticles'. As the leaflet convening the Canberra meeting in August pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: Pornography focuses on the pleasure of one's own body. It is selfish. Art draws one beyond and outside self, to wonder at the mysteries of creation, including human beauty and sexual love.
Everyone who has experienced both, knows that there is an important difference, a line between pornography and art.

The fact is that after months of procrastination the Government has agreed now to this parliamentary inquiry, this Select Committee on Video Censorship. But is is too little too late. In my view its terms of reference can probably now be called adequate but the Committee will not be able to finalise its business until well after the new Parliament meets. It is essential that the Committee that we have just established is not used to sweep the issue under the carpet, and that the Government places a moratorium on those publications incapable of meeting the reasonable adult person test pending the outcome of the parliamentary committee of inquiry. For too long the public has been kept in the dark on these issues and denied their democratic right to an effective say on this issue of major importance to the social well-being of the community. As the whole issue is in such a shambles now, it is only fair that the Government should agree to this motion and should impose a moratorium on that material pending the outcome of the parliamentary committee of inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, the Australian Democrats believe, with great respect to the mover of the motion, that the motion has grave defects. Some of the statements in the motion and its intentions are wildly inaccurate. For instance, this Parliament does not have the power to put any kind of moratorium nationally; that power rests with the States. As I said earlier, the importation of sexually sadistic and violent material is already forbidden as a result of the Customs regulations and amendments passed here in the past. On that basis and with those reservations, we support the general principles of the motion. We will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept that there is a case for a moratorium, particularly in the context of importation, which is now subject to a series of regulations approved by the Australian Democrats themselves and, indeed, trumpeted as an achievement by them . We are confronting yet another inane and timorous flip-flop from the Australian Democrats. They acknowledge that the very terms of the motion before us are silly but nonetheless, because of some concern about electoral implications of behaving otherwise, they are supporting this call for a moratorium.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not believe that the situation in the Australian Capital Territory is such that the fabric of either the Territory or the nation will collapse overnight with the continued operation of what is a quite effectively working ordinance over the next couple of months. Under those circumstances the Government believes it is highly appropriate to let the present situation, which is under very active review by the censorship Ministers, continue for the immediately foreseeable future. Of course it will be reviewed in the light of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Video Censorship and subsequently the joint select committee. Therefore, the Government opposes the motion but does not intend to press it to the point of a division. We do not think it is a very sensible motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that was a hypocritical statement by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). He has supported the motion to set up the Select Committee on Video Censorship, he has said that we need to review the matter, but he will not call a moratorium in the meantime. That is hypocritical.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REPORT OF THE ROYAL COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I address my question to the Attorney-General. I refer to the Attorney's answer to Senator Chaney yesterday about possible problems concerning the cover of parliamentary privilege for the publication of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union if it is not tabled in the Parliament. Is the report expected from Mr Costigan on the 26th of this month or has the deadline been brought forward, as the Prime Minister suggested last week may happen? Does the Attorney agree that it would be totally unacceptable for media coverage of that report to be restricted to certain States because of concern about the question of privilege? Will the Government therefore take the course of action which would remove all doubts; that is, will it recall the House of Representatives and the Senate to receive Mr Costigan's report even if that means a delay of a day or so in the date of the dissolution of the House?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no knowledge of what the current deadline is in relation to the production of the report and I certainly do not have any information that it will in fact be earlier than 26 October. If it is possible to supplement that answer with further more up to date information than I have, I will do that as soon as possible. As to the access of the media and everybody else to the Costigan report in the terms in which it is made available to the Speaker and the President, it is not as satisfactory as it might be to have a situation where there is some uncertainty in some States about the way in which that material might be protected. I make it clear, however, that there will be no uncertainty at all in Victoria and no uncertainty in New South Wales to the extent that the New South Wales legislation is perfectly clear-that material which is absolutely privileged in Victoria is equally so privileged in New South Wales-and the situation will be clear here in the Australian Capital Territory. That still leaves some room for uncertainty in the other States, but I would not wish to exaggerate the extent of that.

ANSWER.PARA: As to a recall of the House of Representatives, that would be quite impractical . As I understand it, the last date possible for the dissolution in order that the election might be held on 1 December is 26 October or thereabouts, and such a recall would completely disrupt the election timetable. In turn, that would create the difficulty-quite apart from the willingness of the majority of honourable senators to reconvene, which is yet another question-which I adverted to yesterday about the Senate purporting to act as a Senate when the House of Representatives has been dissolved. I honestly do not think the question is likely to become a real one. It is begging the question that there will be defamatory material in the report made available to the President and the Speaker and it has been made clear all along that the report in the form in which it is presented to the Government will be very carefully vetted by a number of independent bodies with a view to ensuring that no one is improperly prejudiced by it. Under those circumstances, it may well be unlikely that there will be anything in the report that is very defamatory anyway; but to the extent that there is, the basic protection will be there and any uncertainty is really only very much at the margin.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, refers to the statements regarding the Budget deficit that were made by the former Treasury head, Mr John Stone, and quoted in yesterday's Press. Would the Minister care to tell us what the likely implications would be for his Department and for the veteran community if the prescription put forward by Mr Stone were likely to be implemented?

—There is no doubt that veterans and veterans' organisations, if they realise the full impact of Mr Stone's statement, will appreciate that the Department of Veterans' Affairs would be very much in the firing line as a result of cutbacks in the deficit, which is part of the philosophy espoused by the former head of the Treasury. He stated that the Government should have applied the revenue surge that resulted from the breaking of the drought to reduce the Budget deficit more drastically, rather than to sustaining government programs in the face of the recession. This is the sort of policy on which he advised governments of both political persuasions in recent years, and those policies have been thoroughly discredited. If his recommendations had been applied by this Government, my Department would have had its funds reduced considerably as it is one of the top Budget expenditure departments-it is in the first half dozen-and consequently I would not have been able to get the funds required to improve hospitals, which are in a deplorable condition in comparison with those in the State hospital system. They all require new operating theatres . The wards are of 1942 standard and they require modernising and refurbishing. We would not have been able to carry out our obligations in respect of many of the pension areas if such cuts were introduced. There is no doubt that if veterans fully appreciate the import of the statements they will be very concerned that that sort of person has been advising governments in recent years . It is a clear case of a person who was once a top mandarin now being a pretty sour sort of lemon.

—I refer the Attorney-General to his unconvincing attempt to justify the Government's attitude, and more particularly his own actions over the handling of the Age tapes issue, actions which have been widely condemned by commentators all over Australia in the course of the last seven weeks. In particular, I refer to his claim that, as regards matters covered by State law, there was nothing the Commonwealth could do to pursue investigations because of divisions of power under the Constitution.
